pr_title: [JBTM-3378] LRA recovery manager on top of LRA coordinator

timeline.message:
[JBTM-3378] LRA recovery manager moved on top of the lra coordinator path

Instead of having two separate paths for LRA coordinator and LRA
recovery coordinator at  http://localhost:8080/lra-coordinator and http://localhost:8080/lra-recovery-coordinator
the recovery coordinator will be placed under http://localhost:8080/lra-coordinator
as sub-path  http://localhost:8080/lra-coordinator/recovery

[JBTM-3378] LRA recovery manager moved on top of the lra coordinator path

Instead of having two separate paths for LRA coordinator and LRA
recovery coordinator at  http://localhost:8080/lra-coordinator and http://localhost:8080/lra-recovery-coordinator
the recovery coordinator will be placed under http://localhost:8080/lra-coordinator
as sub-path  http://localhost:8080/lra-coordinator/recovery

timeline.bodyText:
Quote: "A @path value isn’t required to have leading or trailing slashes (/). The JAX-RS runtime parses URI path templates the same whether or not they have leading or trailing spaces."
So in this example you do not need the Path annotation at all.
timeline.author: mmusgrov

timeline.bodyText: What was intended? The original code with the explicit if branch was clearer.
timeline.author: mmusgrov

replies.bodyText: The intend is to make the path dynamic. When the coordinator is run with Quarkus the path is explicit. But in case of e.g. WildFly the path depends on the deployment name. The deployment name may differ for every test.
replies.author: ochaloup

replies.bodyText: oh, I'm sorry for that. I misunderstood your point. When you consider prior code cleaner I will change it back.
replies.author: ochaloup

timeline.bodyText: These comments are confusing and it's not clear why they need to be included.
timeline.author: mmusgrov

replies.bodyText: I rephrased the text. I hope it will be better now.
replies.author: ochaloup

timeline.bodyText: ... and the implementation is even harder to understand.
timeline.author: mmusgrov

replies.bodyText:
And it is 35 lines long. That seems excessive since there is a simple one liner (or some variant of it):
String getUid(URI lraId) {return lraId.getPath().substring(path.lastIndexOf('/') + 1);
replies.author: mmusgrov

replies.bodyText: I agree with Mike here, we could use the more efficient method and could give the explanation in java docs?
replies.author: mayankkunwar

replies.bodyText: Ok. I changed the method. It's not a one liner but it's shorter and similar.
replies.author: ochaloup

timeline.author: mmusgrov

timeline.bodyText:
Why are we testing internals.
If our code is constructing invalid LRA ids then a majority of tests will end up failing.
These tests are just adding noise to our code base.
timeline.author: mmusgrov
timeline.diffHunk:

+public class NarayanaLRARecoveryTest {

+    @Test
+    public void extractCoordinatorFromUsualLRAId() {

replies.bodyText:
I don't think so. This is a unit test which is normal to be used to check the functionality of particular parts of a class. The tests help to do changes and refactoring and not breaking the functionality.
The integration tests are the next step in the testing journey that verifies how the whole machinery works together.
replies.author: ochaloup

replies.bodyText: Unit tests are the first step of testing, I agree.
replies.author: mayankkunwar

replies.bodyText: After thinking about this I would like to preserve the unit test. I'm in agreement with Mayank here.
replies.author: ochaloup
